items.title: Rachel Reeves plans £7.5bn tax rise in budget after U-turn on income tax rates
items.standfirst: Chancellor expected to freeze level at which people start paying income tax for two years rather than putting rates upRachel Reeves will raise £7.5bn from millions of workers by freezing tax thresholds at the budget, after her decision to scrap controversial plans to raise income tax led to a sell-off in the bond market.Government sources said the chancellor had decided to maintain the level at which people start paying income tax for two years while abandoning plans to raise the headline rate, which would have broken a manifesto promise. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Anthropic says financial firms and government agencies were attacked ‘largely without human intervention’A leading artificial intelligence company claims to have stopped a China-backed “cyber espionage” campaign that was able to infiltrate financial firms and government agencies with almost no human oversight.The US-based Anthropic said its coding tool, Claude Code, was “manipulated” by a Chinese state-sponsored group to attack 30 entities around the world in September, achieving a “handful of successful intrusions”. U.S. tariffs on Swiss goods will be reduced to fifteen percent.
The deal resolves a months-long trade dispute.
The agreement was announced by Swiss officials.

The deal is part of a new trade pact.

clusters.title: UN peacekeepers say Israel built walls inside Lebanese territory
clusters.neutral_headline: UN Peacekeepers Say Israel Built Walls

items.title: UN peacekeepers say Israel built walls inside Lebanese territory
items.standfirst: UNIFIL says it asked Israeli army to move walls, which cross unofficial 'Blue Line' border between Lebanon and Israel.
items.content: UNIFIL says it asked Israeli army to move walls, which cross unofficial 'Blue Line' border between Lebanon and Israel.

items.title: Israel army denies building wall inside Lebanon after UN forces say de facto border crossed
items.standfirst: UN peacekeepers on Friday said that Israel built new concrete walls that crossed the Blue Line into Lebanese territory, urging a withdrawal. Israel denied any breach of the UN-demarcated border.
items.content: UN peacekeepers on Friday said that Israel built new concrete walls that crossed the Blue Line into Lebanese territory, urging a withdrawal. Israel denied any breach of the UN-demarcated border.

ai_summary: UN peacekeepers stated Israel built walls inside Lebanon.
The walls cross the unofficial "Blue Line" border.
UNIFIL asked the Israeli army to move the walls.
Israel denies building the walls.

clusters.title: 'Work, work, work!' Japan's new PM under fire for asking staff to come in at 3am
clusters.neutral_headline: Japan Prime Minister's Sleep Schedule Concerns

items.title: 'Work, work, work!' Japan's new PM under fire for asking staff to come in at 3am
items.standfirst: When she was elected head of Japan's ruling party, Sanae Takaichi declared that she had abandoned the term "work-life balance" and asked fellow party members to "work like a horse". A month into office, the country's first female prime minister appears to have put her words into action. She told parliament that she was only sleeping two to four hours at night, a few days after organising a 3am staff meeting. In a country plagued by a culture of overwork, this hasn't gone down well.
items.content: When she was elected head of Japan's ruling party, Sanae Takaichi declared that she had abandoned the term "work-life balance" and asked fellow party members to "work like a horse". A month into office, the country's first female prime minister appears to have put her words into action. She told parliament that she was only sleeping two to four hours at night, a few days after organising a 3am staff meeting. In a country plagued by a culture of overwork, this hasn't gone down well.

items.title: Two hours a night: Japan PM’s sleep schedule prompts concerns about work-life balance
items.standfirst: Takaichi caused a stir last week after she summoned aides to her office for a 3am meeting to prepare for a budget committee hearingJapan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, has said she gets by on just two to four hours sleep a night – prompting concern over her commitment to a better work-life balance among the country’s fatigued employees.Pointing to the bags beneath her eyes, Takaichi told MPs that she survives on minimal sleep – a habit she shares with her political hero Margaret Thatcher – after being asked how she would tackle Japan’s notoriously long working hours. Continue reading...
items.content: Takaichi caused a stir last week after she summoned aides to her office for a 3am meeting to prepare for a budget committee hearingJapan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, has said she gets by on just two to four hours sleep a night – prompting concern over her commitment to a better work-life balance among the country’s fatigued employees.Pointing to the bags beneath her eyes, Takaichi told MPs that she survives on minimal sleep – a habit she shares with her political hero Margaret Thatcher – after being asked how she would tackle Japan’s notoriously long working hours. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Japan's Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, sleeps two to four hours nightly.
She organized a 3 AM staff meeting.
She stated she abandoned the term "work-life balance".
Her schedule has caused concern about overwork.

items.content: UN rights chief urges countries to 'stand up against atrocities' committed by paramilitary RSF in takeover of the city.

items.title: UN rights council orders probe of atrocities in Sudan's El-Fasher amid genocide warnings
items.standfirst: The UN Human Rights Council on Friday ordered a probe into alleged atrocities in Sudan’s El-Fasher, acting amid stark warnings of crimes against humanity and genocide.
items.content: The UN Human Rights Council on Friday ordered a probe into alleged atrocities in Sudan’s El-Fasher, acting amid stark warnings of crimes against humanity and genocide.

ai_summary: The UN Human Rights Council ordered an investigation.
The probe concerns alleged atrocities in El-Fasher, Sudan.
Warnings of crimes against humanity and genocide exist.
The atrocities are attributed to the RSF.

clusters.title: A 'dirty neck,' 'evil witch': Why a furious China is unleashing on Japan's new leader
clusters.neutral_headline: China and Japan in Diplomatic Spat

items.title: A 'dirty neck,' 'evil witch': Why a furious China is unleashing on Japan's new leader
items.standfirst: China and Japan are locked in a furious diplomatic spat after Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi said an attack on Taiwan could draw a military response from Tokyo.
items.content: China and Japan are locked in a furious diplomatic spat after Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi said an attack on Taiwan could draw a military response from Tokyo.

items.title: China summons Japan ambassador as war of words over Taiwan drags on
items.standfirst: Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi had suggested Tokyo could take military action if Beijing attacked Taiwan.
items.content: Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi had suggested Tokyo could take military action if Beijing attacked Taiwan.

ai_summary: China and Japan are in a diplomatic dispute.
The dispute follows comments by Japan's PM.
The PM said Tokyo might respond militarily to an attack on Taiwan.
China summoned the Japanese ambassador.
